[[Ostrowski Prize]] (2007) |religion = |signature = |footnotes = }} '''Oded Schramm''' ({{lang-he|עודד שרם}}) (December 10, 1961 – September 1, 2008) was an [[Israel]]i-[[United States|American]] [[mathematician]] known for the invention of the [[Schramm–Loewner evolution]] (SLE) and for working at the intersection of [[conformal field theory]] and [[probability theory]].{{cite web| title = Clay Mathematics Institute| accessdate = 2008-09-12| url = http://www.claymath.org/research_award/Schramm/}}{{citation|first=Gregory F.|last=Lawler|authorlink=Greg Lawler|series=Mathematical Surveys and Monographs|volume=114|title=Conformally Invariant Processes in the Plane|publisher=American Mathematical Society|year=2005|isbn=0-8218-3677-3|location=Providence, RI|mr=2129588}} ==Biography== Schramm was born in [[Jerusalem]] in [[Israel]]. His father, Michael Schramm, was a biochemistry professor at the [[Hebrew University]] of Jerusalem. He attended [[Hebrew University]] where he received his [[bachelor’s degree]] in mathematics and computer science in 1986 and his [[master's degree]] in 1987, under the supervision of [[Gil Kalai]]. He then received his [[Ph.D.]] from [[Princeton University]] in 1990 under the supervision of [[William Thurston]]. After receiving his doctorate, he worked for two years at the [[University of California, San Diego]], and then had a permanent position at the [[Weizmann Institute]] from 1992 to 1999. In 1999 he moved to the Theory Group at [[Microsoft Research]] in [[Redmond, Washington]], where he remained for the rest of his life. He and his wife had two children. On September 1, 2008, Schramm fell to his death while solo climbing [[Guye Peak]], north of [[Snoqualmie Pass]] in [[Washington (state)|Washington]].{{citation | last = Chang | first = Kenneth | date = September 10, 2008 | journal = [[New York Times]] | title = Oded Schramm, 46, Mathematician, Is Dead | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/11/science/11schramm.html}}{{citation | last = Gutierrez | first = Scott | date = September 3, 2008 | journal = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] | title = Rescuers recover hiker's body near Cascades' Guye Peak | url = http://www.seattlepi.com/local/377577_hiker04.html}}{{citation | date = September 4, 2008 | journal = [[Seattle Times]] | title = Accomplished Microsoft mathematician died in hiking accident | url = http://blog.seattletimes.nwsource.com/techtracks/2008/09/04/accomplished_microsoft_mathematician_died_in_hikin.html}} ==Research== [[Image:circleRiemannMap1.svg|right|thumb|180px|An illustration by Schramm.]] A constant theme in Schramm's research was the exploration of relations between discrete models and their continuous scaling limits, which for a number of models turn out to be [[conformally invariant]]. Schramm's most significant contribution is the invention of [[Schramm–Loewner evolution]], a tool which has paved the way for mathematical proofs of conjectured scaling limit relations{{citation|title=Critical percolation in finite geometries|first=John|last= Cardy|authorlink=John Cardy|year= 1992| journal=J. Phys. A: Math. Gen.|volume= 25|pages= L201–L206|url=http://www.iop.org/EJ/abstract/0305-4470/25/4/009/|doi=10.1088/0305-4470/25/4/009|bibcode=1992JPhA...25L.201C|arxiv = hep-th/9111026|issue=4|mr=1151081}}{{citation |url=http://www.iop.org/EJ/article/0305-4470/35/41/102/a241l2.html|first=John|last=Cardy|authorlink=John Cardy|journal=J. Phys. A: Math. Gen.|volume= 35 |pages= L565–L572|year=2002|title=Crossing formulae for critical percolation in an annulus |doi=10.1088/0305-4470/35/41/102 |issue=41|mr=1946958}} on models from [[statistical mechanics]] such as [[self-avoiding walk|self-avoiding random walk]] and [[percolation]]. This technique has had a profound impact on the field. It has been recognized by many awards to Schramm and others, including a [[Fields Medal]] to [[Wendelin Werner]], who was one of Schramm's principal collaborators, along with [[Gregory Lawler]]. The [[New York Times]] wrote in his obituary: {{cquote|If Dr. Schramm had been born three weeks and a day later, he would almost certainly have been one of the winners of the Fields Medal, perhaps the highest honor in mathematics, in 2002.}} Schramm's doctorate {{citation | title=Combinatorically Prescribed Packings and Applications to Conformal and Quasiconformal Maps|format=modified version of Schramm's Ph.D. thesis from 1990|year=2007|first=Oded|last=Schramm|arxiv=0709.0710|bibcode = 2007PhDT.......441S | volume=0709 | pages=710 }}. was in [[complex analysis]], but he made contributions in many other areas of pure mathematics, although self-taught in those areas. Frequently he would prove a result by himself before reading the literature to obtain an appropriate credit. Often his proof was original or more elegant than the original.{{citation | date = September 19, 2008 | journal = [[Daily Telegraph]] | title = Mathematician who made a significant contribution to the study of probability and fractals | url = http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/2984516/Oded-Schramm.html}} Besides conformally invariant planar processes and SLE, he made fundamental contributions to several topics:{{cite web | title = Oded Schramm's publications on Google Scholar | url = http://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=Oded+Schramm}} * [[Circle packing]]s and discrete [[conformal geometry]]. * Embeddings of [[Gromov hyperbolic space]]s. * [[Percolation theory|Percolation]], [[uniform spanning tree|uniform]] and [[minimal spanning tree|minimal]] spanning trees and forests, [[harmonic function]]s on [[Cayley graph]]s of infinite finitely generated groups (especially [[amenable group|non-amenable groups]]) and the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. * Limits of sequences of finite [[graph (mathematics)|graphs]]. * Noise sensitivity of [[Boolean function]]s, with applications to dynamical percolation. * Random turn games (e.g. random turn [[hex (board game)|hex]]) and the [[infinity Laplacian]] equation. * [[Random permutation]]s. ==Awards and honors== *[[Erdős Prize]] (1996)[ftp://ftp.math.technion.ac.il/imu/erdos_prize.html#english The Anna and Lajos Erdős Prize in Mathematics], [[Technion]]. *[[Salem Prize]] (2001){{citation|url=http://www.ams.org/notices/200108/people.pdf|title=Schramm and Smirnov Awarded 2001 Salem
